Description: Scaraboid carved from beige soft steatite in the shape of a hedgehog; back detailed by fine incisions and inscribed with hieroglyphs arranged vertically in oval (or cartouche), very eroded; underside bearing incised motif arranged vertically composed of a winged mythical creature (ram-headed lion or griffin?) and a crocodile, surmounted by a sun-disc framed by uraei, with neb-basket sign underneath; fine hatching within figures; pierced longitudinally.
Curator's comments: Published as a scaraboid in glazed composition, not stone (Petrie 1886, pl. XXXVII, no. 14). Only one attestation is known to Jaeger for a name of Menkheperra linked with the epithet “Lord of the Sed festival” (Jaeger 1982, § 181). The style of the motif on the underside is reminiscent of the Phoenician style displayed in Gorton's type XV (Gorton 1996, 43-48). Hedgehog scaraboids are, however, not listed in the types of scaraboids known for this type (only round cones and African heads). For a good Phoenician parallel, see hedgehog scaraboid from Aschkelon: Oxford, Ashomolean Museum WAA 1889.578 (Keel 1997, 688-9, no. 2). The overall shape and style of the motif are very similar to the Naukratis specimen, but the central band on the back of the hedgehog is left blank. Jaeger, B. 1982, Essai de classification et datation des scarabées Menkhéperrê. Fribourg. Keel, O. 1997, Corpus der Stempelsiegel-Amulette aus Palästina/Israel : von den Anfängen bis zur Perserzeit (Orbis Biblicus et Orientalis, Series Archaeologica 29), Fribourg. Petrie, W.M.F. 1886, Naukratis. Part I, 1884–5 (Third Memoir of the Egypt Exploration Fund), London.
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. XXXVII, no. 14)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (OB.10) (phase 3)
